conclusion: Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
Acceleration of object A is constant; acceleration of object B increases linearly.
At time t1, the area under the acceleration-time curve for object A is a rectangle with height a and width t1, giving a velocity of vA = a*t1.
For object B, the area under the curve is a triangle with base t1 and height a, giving a velocity of vB = 0.5*a*t1.
Since vA is not equal to vB, the two objects do not have the same velocity at time t1.
